communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the North Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Greta Moran

communications.subject: NC Dept of Labor Public Records Request
communications.communication:
Greta Moran
MuckRock News, DEPT MR131353
263 Huntington Ave
Boston, Massachusetts. 02115
131353-61094228@requests.muckrock.com<mailto:131353-61094228@requests.muckrock.com>

Ms. Moran,
You submitted a public records request to the NC Department of Labor on 07/13/2022 regarding Occupational Safety and Health inspections performed on Lorillard, Inc., Alliance One International., Reynolds American Inc., Liggett Vector Brands LLC, and Imperial Tobacco PLC.
It is my understanding that you have been provided the OSH inspection information from PSIM, but an additional part of your requests was "all of the agency's e-mail correspondences with any of the follow tobacco companies, Lorillard, Inc., Alliance One International., Reynolds American Inc., Liggett Vector Brands LLC. Imperial Tobacco PLC, between January 1, 2020 and present."  Based on what you have requested, I have to run email searches separate from the OSH inspection information because emails are maintained in a separate system. Due to the sensitive nature of emails, I am the only authorized person within the agency with all email access who may run such a search.
To date, I have attempted to run the requested company names in a myriad of ways, but because of the commonality of several words  (e.g., alliance, brands, tobacco) and your request for "all of the agency's email correspondence" (no specific NC Dept of Labor employee), I am getting thousands of emails that include those words; further, the search must be run through all 350+ NCDOL employees, so each search is taking several hours to run.  I then have to review the emails to see if the email is applicable to your request, such as only referring to "Alliance One International" instead of some other Alliance One reference.  I have continued to attempt to refine the searches, in an attempt to produce a more reasonable-sized list. Please be advised that based on my prior attempts, I must advise you that it will  take me extensive time to go through such information.
Is there a way you can refine your request or narrow the time frame?  Are there any specific NCDOL employees that may have been corresponding with these companies or are there specific email addresses within those named companies that I could use to refine the search?  Any information would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you.

Jill F. Cramer
General Counsel
NC Department of Labor
Direct: 919-707-7710
Main Legal Affairs: 919-707-7713

Mailing Address:
1101 Mail Service Center
Raleigh, NC   27699-1101
jill.cramer@labor.nc.gov<mailto:jill.cramer@labor.nc.gov>

Please visit our website at www.labor.nc.gov<http://www.nclabor.com/>

NOTICE:  E-mail correspondence to and from this sender may be subject to the North Carolina Public Records Law and may be disclosed to third parties.  This e-mail and all attachments transmitted with it may contain legally privileged and confidential information intended solely for the use of the addressee.  If the reader of this message is not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any reading, dissemination, distribution, copying, or other use of this message or its attachments is strictly prohibited.

If you have received this message in error, please notify the sender immediately by telephone  or by electronic mail, and delete this message.


________________________________

Email correspondence to and from this address may be subject to the North Carolina Public Records Law and may be disclosed to third parties by an authorized state official.

Dear Jill,

Thank you for your time, and thorough consideration, in assisting me with this. I apologize for my delay in replying to your earlier correspondence. 

Would it make your search more feasible if I added in some of the key words that I am looking for? 

I would like to request all of the agency's e-mail correspondences, containing  one or all of the phrases, "heat illness," "extreme heat," "breaks," "Green Tobacco Sickness," "pesticide poisoning,"  with any of the following tobacco companies, Lorillard, Inc., Alliance One International., Reynolds American Inc., Liggett Vector Brands LLC. Imperial Tobacco PLC, between January 1, 2020 and present.

Please let me know if this would help. I'm also happy to discuss other possibilities for refining the request over the phone (917-405-8270), if easier. 

Best
Greta Moran

communications.subject: RE: NC Dept of Labor Public Records Request

I continue to try different ways to run the searches to produce more reasonable batches through which to search.

As you may know, our agency provides training on green tobacco illness along with other hazards to which agricultural employees may be exposed.

communications.subject: RE: [External] RE: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: E-mail Correspondences with Tobacco Companies (North Carolina Department Of Labor)
communications.communication:
Greta
I am working to complete this today.  I have gone through all the search files produced in my efforts except the Alliance One International search; that search produced the largest search file.  I am attaching all the emails that I located as of today, which you have not previously been provided by the Planning, Statistics, and Information Management Bureau (PSIM).  PSIM is the custodian of all the OSH files.

Please note that some of the emails reference Boiler Safety inspections, which also falls under the jurisdiction of the NC Department of Labor.

I did locate an email containing a Liggett Vector OSH complaint file (#209713353), but the complaint was related to feces that was repeatedly being spread in a bathroom on the site.

Please be advised that this agency also enforces the NC Retaliatory Employment Discrimination Act (REDA), which may be found here: https://www.ncleg.net/enactedlegislation/statutes/HTML/byarticle/chapter_95/Article_21.html

I found emails associated to two REDA complaints related to RJ Reynolds.  Whereas neither the email nor the complaints referenced green tobacco illness or heat stress, I did want to apprise you of their existence. Those complaint files would have to be requested separately and cannot be released unless they are closed.  They would also be redacted prior to being released. The REDA complaint investigations are listed as follows:

  1.  REDA Complaint # 60897
  2.  REDA Complaint # 202769



I will be back in touch once I have completed the Alliance One search.


Jill F. Cramer
General Counsel

communications.subject: RE: [External] RE: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: E-mail Correspondences with Tobacco Companies (North Carolina Department Of Labor)
communications.communication:
Greta
Just as an FYI, most tobacco is grown by growers, then sold to the large tobacco companies. I relate this information to you primarily because the terms you indicated (green tobacco illness, heat stress) probably will have little to no connections directly the listed tobacco companies in relation to potential Occupational Safety and Health complaints.

In relation to that, growers or Farm Labor Contractors (FLC) would be the more likely employer of workers.  The FLC’s generally recruit and hire seasonal or temporary agricultural laborers; in addition, they may also transport, house, and provide meals for workers.  FLC’s are required to obtain a federal certification: https://www.dol.gov/agencies/whd/agriculture/mspa/farm-labor-contractors.   Here is an actual US Department of Labor news release: https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/whd/whd20210804-0.  Further, H2A workers fare certified under the authority of the US Department of Labor; see this article: https://www.dol.gov/agencies/whd/agriculture/h2a/final-rule

Please also be apprised that NC Department of Labor participates in an advisory capacity to a group that also includes Alliance One International, Inc. The group is the Farm Labor Practices Group (FLPG), which states that it “is a multi-stakeholder initiative, formed in 2012, committed to improving labor practices on farms and thereby enhancing the farmworker’s experience.  The FLPG brings together key voices representing different sectors and perspectives, including growers/farmers, worker advocates, manufacturers and others who sell agricultural products, and government agencies.  The work of the FLPG is facilitated by a third party, the Keystone Policy Center, and includes the following member organizations.” https://farmlaborpracticesgroup.org/about-us/

https://www.keystone.org/our-work/agriculture/farm-labor-practices-group/

•           Alliance One International, Inc.  (global HQ is in Morrisville, NC)
•           Altria Client Services LLC
•           Consulate General of Mexico in Raleigh*
•           Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility
•           North Carolina Agribusiness Council, Inc.*
•           North Carolina Agromedicine Institute*
•           North Carolina Department of Agriculture & Consumer Services*
•           North Carolina Department of Commerce – Division of Workforce Solutions*
•           North Carolina Department of Labor – Agricultural Safety and Health*
•           North Carolina Farm Bureau*
•           Phillip Morris International (PMI)
•           RAI Service Company
•           Tobacco Growers Association of North Carolina
•           Universal Leaf Tobacco Company, Inc
•           U.S. Department of Labor – Wage and Hour Division
*Advisory member

Beth Rodman, the Bureau Chief of the Agricultural Safety and Health Bureau of the Occupational Safety and Health Division, is the NCDOL employee who participates in FLPG workgroups that meet regularly such as the Training and Education workgroup and the FLC workgroup.  In relation to FLPG, she noted that many concerns related to FLCs are outside of the scope of the NC Department of Labor’s statutory authority.  Examples include wage issues (because they fall under USDOL and not NCDOL), contractual violations, visa fraud, recruitment concerns, human trafficking (all of which are outside of this agency’s statutory authority). Therefore, there will be multiple emails included related to this group.  If you do NOT want any of these emails, please let me know.

I created another pdf that I attempted to attach, but it is too large; I will have to recreate it into smaller files.  I will send the final set next week.


Jill F. Cramer
General Counsel
NC Department of Labor
Direct: 919-707-7710
Main Legal Affairs: 919-707-7713

1101 Mail Service Center
Raleigh, NC   27699-1101

title: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing
communications.communication:
To whoever it may concern: 

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, G.L. c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your school district. Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act,  school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE).   DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement.  DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.  

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”  

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”   


I request the following public records, as defined in G. L. c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth): 

1.	An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a.	Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b.	Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c.	Charge (or charges)
d.	Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f.	Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g.	Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h.	Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i.	Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j.	Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k.	Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l.	Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2.	If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide school incident reports on each school-related arrest and referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 

3.	A copy of any active standard operating procedures developed with the police department and/or other law enforcement agencies regarding police placement or activity in your corresponding school;  and,

4.	Any records instructing or informing police personnel of, or otherwise describing data reporting requirements and procedures for complying with G.L. c. 71 § 37P(b).

5.	The cost to the school district of assigning a school resource officer to each school; and, 

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and, 

8.	A description of the proposed budget for mental, social, or emotional health support personnel for the school district.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.  To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me by phone at (617)-373-5862 or by email at k.stathulis@northeastern.edu. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.
	
Sincerely, 


Katherine Stathulis, Esq.
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: DOI Investigations into DOE employee
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Copies of any and all investigations and conclusions regarding former DOE employee Tommy Torres, and/or copies of any and all correspondence or referrals made to other investigatory bodies related to Tommy Torres dating between 2006-2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Gwynne Hogan

communications.subject: [OpenRecords] Request FOIL-2023-032-00050 Closed
communications.communication:
The Department of Investigation (DOI) has closed your FOIL request FOIL-2023-032-00050 for the following reasons: (https://a860-openrecords.nyc.gov/request/view/FOIL-2023-032-00050) 
 Your request under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) is denied in part and granted in part for the reasons stated below. Responsive document was uploaded into Open Records on March 24, 2023 Some redactions have been made where (1) the information relates to allegations that DOI deemed unsubstantiated; and (2) the information could be used to identify witnesses who cooperated with our investigation and were not found to have engaged in wrongdoing. See generally Public Officers Law § 87(2)(b); Committee on Open Government Advisory Opinion 17195 (May 29, 2008) (“to the extent that charges are dismissed or allegations are found to be without merit, I believe that they may be withheld based on considerations of privacy”); Committee on Open Government Advisory Opinion AO-12802 (July 13, 2001)(noting that the exemption pertaining to the personal privacy could be invoked to shield the identities of witnesses).  
You may appeal the decision to deny access to material that was redacted in part or withheld in entirety by contacting the agency's FOIL Appeals Officer: FOILAppeals@doi.nyc.gov within 30 days. (mailto:FOILAppeals@doi.nyc.gov?subject=FOIL-2023-032-00050%20-%20Appeal)

title: FOIA - Email Aliases (Mayor's Office)

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: FOIA - Email Aliases (Mayor's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

A CSV export of your agency's Email Aliases (see https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/email/add-another-email-alias-for-a-user?view=o365-worldwide ) including the following parameters for every shared mailbox:

- Primary SMTP Address
- Name of the alias
- Name of Mailbox

A simple way to retrieve this is by having a member of IT (such as a System Administrator) run the following command in Exchange Online PowerShell (if email is hosted in a Microsoft Exchange environment):


Get-Mailbox | Select-Object DisplayName,RecipientType,PrimarySmtpAddress, @{Name="Aliases";Expression={$_.EmailAddresses | Where-Object {$_ -clike "smtp:*"}}} | Export-Csv ./email_aliases.csv

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

J Ader

Please find the attached records responsive to your request. We have redacted certain material pursuant to Section 7(1)(c) of FOIA.  That section exempts: 

[p]ersonal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subjects of the information.  ‘Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy’ means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in in which the subject’s right of privacy outweighs any legitimate public interest in obtaining the information.  The disclosure of information that bears on the public duties of public employees and officials shall not be considered an invasion of personal privacy. 
We have redacted under Section 7(1)(c) certain City issued email addresses.  As publicly-available certain City issued email addresses would subject these employees to invasive and unsolicited communications, the disclosure of this information would burden employees’ privacy interest. Additionally, the access to this information would not advance the public interest in understanding “the affairs of government and the official acts and policies of those who represent them[.]” 5 ILCS 140/1. Further, the landline numbers and other email addresses for these employees is available to the public, which further limits the de minimis public interest in the contact information of the requested employees. See Shurtleff v. United States Environmental Protection Agency, 991 F. Supp. 2d 1, 18 (D.D.C. Sept. 30, 2013) (“The EPA has proferred a substantial privacy interest at stake in disclosing the official internal email address of the EPA Administrator and the work email address of employees at the EOP: these few individuals have ‘a significant personal interest in preventing the burden of unsolicited emails and harassment.’”); Buckovetz v. U.S. Department of the Navy, Case No. 14-cv-2115-BEN, 2016 WL 4801335 at *2-3 (S.D. Cal. Apr. 7, 2016) (affirming the redaction of an employee’s cell phone number, because “the [employee’s] privacy rights in this information outweigh the public’s interest in disclosure”).” You have the right to have a denial reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General, 500 S. 2nd Street, Springfield, Illinois 62701, (877) 299-3642. You may also seek judicial review of a denial under 5 ILCS 140/11 of FOIA. If you have any questions or need additional information, please feel free to contact my office at 312-744-3844. Sincerely, Thomas Skelton 
FOIA Officer 
Mayor's Office

title: FOIL Request for Records Related to Communications with American Academy of Pediatrics and Council on School Health (North Colonie Central School District)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: FOIL Request for Records Related to Communications with American Academy of Pediatrics and Council on School Health (North Colonie Central School District)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am seeking all records related to the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and the Council on School Health (COSH), including any communications or correspondence between the school district and these organizations, or any other party that may have provided information to the district from these organizations.

To help identify responsive records, you can limit your time period to 1/1/2017 until the date of final response; also I request that you search for the following terms, which are focused on the American Academy of Pediatrics and its affiliated organizations:

"American Academy of Pediatrics"
"AAP"
"Council on School Health"
"COSH"
"pediatric"
"child health"
"school health"

Please include records of any type, including but not limited to emails, letters, memoranda, reports, meeting minutes, presentations, and any other records of communication or correspondence between the American Academy of Pediatrics, the Council on School Health, and the school district or any other party that may have provided information to the district from these organizations.

If no records are responsive to this request, please provide a certification of that fact pursuant to Public Officers Law §89(3), and inform me of the district's obligations under LGS-01 to retain records until any appeal has been resolved.

If any records are withheld, please provide an explanation of the legal basis for the withholding.

If my request is denied in whole or in part, please provide a written explanation of the reasons for the denial.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jackson Parker

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: FOIL Request for Records Related to Communications with American Academy of Pediatrics and Council on School Health (North Colonie Central School District)
communications.communication:
I am writing to appeal a failure to respond to my FOIL request made on 3/7/23. The request was for records related to the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and the Council on School Health (COSH), including any communications or correspondence between the school district and these organizations, or any other party that may have provided information to the district from these organizations. To help identify responsive records, I requested a search of specific terms.

As of today's date, I have not received a response to my FOIL request. Therefore, I am appealing the lack of response and request that you conduct a diligent search for responsive records and provide them to me in a timely manner.

Furthermore, I would like to modify my original request to narrow the affiliated organizations list to remove references to "pediatric," "child health," and "school health." This modification will allow for a more specific and reasonable description of the records being requested.

Please inform me of the district's obligations under LGS-01 to retain records until any appeal has been resolved. If any records are withheld, please provide an explanation of the legal basis for the withholding.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response.

communications.subject: RE: Georgia Open Records Act Request: 1/18/23 Incident Report (Department Of Public Safety, Georgia State Patrol)
communications.communication:
Thank you for your response. Per OCGA § 50-18-72(4):

Records of law enforcement, prosecution, or regulatory agencies in any pending investigation 
or prosecution of criminal or unlawful activity, **other than initial police arrest reports and initial 
incident reports**; provided, however, that an investigation or prosecution shall no longer be 
deemed to be pending when all direct litigation involving such investigation and prosecution has 
become final or otherwise terminated; and provided, further, that this paragraph shall not apply 
to records in the possession of an agency that is the subject of the pending investigation or 
prosecution; and provided, further, that the release of booking photographs shall only be 
permissible in accordance with Code Section 35-1-18

Therefore we again request the initial incident/arrests reports and the CAD report.

Thank you.

Good day,

The incident and Use of Force reports are complete, please see attached.  DPS will seek reimbursement pursuant to our charging chart and consistent with Georgia law.  For fee information, please see O.C.G.A. §50-18-71.  You may review our charging chart at https://dps.georgia.gov/charging-fees-open-records-requests<https://linkprotect.cudasvc.com/url?a=https%3a%2f%2fdps.georgia.gov%2fcharging-fees-open-records-requests&c=E,1,2HE9mQf0XNGxMWAYFcfiika7IA_x3lbMz56Euf2io-FL37qf9hcXtiSnJ-B8GcNFN5qTup7dd6bK9ewWCtCVCsU_2IlonS_o_S_N6UtZI9mXGyaP9xK91X0,&typo=1>.  The records have been redacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 50-18-72(a)(21) and (a)(25)(A)(iv).  The cost is $2.00.  To pay via a credit or debit card please use our EPORTs system (www.gadps-eports.net<http://www.gadps-eports.net>) and reference the ORU# MEDI15515423.  Or you may mail a check or money order along with the attached invoice to:

Georgia Department of Public Safety
Attention: Open Records Manager
PO Box 1456
Atlanta, GA 30371

Please make sure to reference your check with ORU# MEDI15515423.

You may receive an email from our online system “EPORTS” that your request has been completed.  You may use the link provided to pay via credit or debit card.  Please note that there are no records to download, the records have been attached to this email.  Please disregard any error message.

Note:
•             Payment must be received within two weeks in lieu of applicable statutory penalties. See O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(d).
•             The charges provided are not copy fees.  The charges provided constitute a sum which is lower than the pro-rated salary for search, retrieval, review, redaction and production by each of the lowest paid full-time employees who, in the reasonable discretion of the Department, has the necessary skill and training to locate and provide responsive documents in each category listed.  See O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(b)(3).
•             The charges provided constitute an automatic 15-minute reduction in each category of fees, which assures that such flat-fees are well-below the statutory guideline.

Thank you,

Nkenge Green

Georgia Department of Public Safety

title: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing
communications.communication:
To whoever it may concern: 

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, G.L. c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your school district. Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act,  school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE).   DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement.  DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.  

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”  

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”   


I request the following public records, as defined in G. L. c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth): 

1.	An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a.	Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b.	Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c.	Charge (or charges)
d.	Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f.	Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g.	Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h.	Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i.	Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j.	Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k.	Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l.	Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2.	If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide school incident reports on each school-related arrest and referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 

3.	A copy of any active standard operating procedures developed with the police department and/or other law enforcement agencies regarding police placement or activity in your corresponding school;  and,

4.	Any records instructing or informing police personnel of, or otherwise describing data reporting requirements and procedures for complying with G.L. c. 71 § 37P(b).

5.	The cost to the school district of assigning a school resource officer to each school; and, 

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and, 

8.	A description of the proposed budget for mental, social, or emotional health support personnel for the school district.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.  To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me by phone at (617)-373-5862 or by email at k.stathulis@northeastern.edu. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.
	
Sincerely, 


Katherine Stathulis, Esq.
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law
